tossups.question: Two compositions in this genre by Johann Vanhal and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart are nicknamed for publisher Joseph Hoffmeister. Anton Reicha [RAY-khah] composed eight pieces in this genre in Vienna. Ignaz Schuppanzigh premiered many Classical works written for this ensemble. A piece in this genre had its sixth and final movement replaced by an Allegro in B-flat major due to its original ending’s (*) dissonant quality. Collections of them by another composer are named “Erdődy” [AIR-der-dee] and “Sun.” The original finale of the 13th one of these compositions by Beethoven is known as the Grosse Fuge. For 10 points, name these non-symphony compositions pioneered by Joseph Haydn, written for two violins, a viola, and a cello.
tossups.answer: string quartets [prompt on quartets] <EX, Music>

tossups.question: David Attwell’s interviews with this author appear in the essay collection Doubling the Point. A novel by this author includes eight “lessons,” the sixth of which centers on Paul West’s book The Very Rich Hours of Count von Stauffenberg. The last line of a novel by this author states “Yes, I am giving him up”, referring to an injured dog that a man is about to euthanize. This author created a character who delivers a lecture on animal (*) rights, and who gained fame with her novel The House on Eccles Street. He wrote a novel in which an affair with a student ends the career of a professor named David Lurie. For 10 points, name this South African author of Elizabeth Costello and Disgrace.
tossups.answer: J. M. Coetzee [coot-ZEE-uh or coot-zee] [or John Maxwell Coetzee] <RY, LongFic>

tossups.question: An advisor named Salman the Persian suggested digging a ditch around this city during a battle in which the Qaynuqa [kay-NOO-keh] people broke its founding charter to besiege it. Many locals in this city, such as the Aws, were given the designation Ansar. People from this city were permitted to go on pilgrimages to a certain place by the treaty of Hudaybiyyah. A violation of a pact with this city’s leaders led to the execution of the Jewish tribe of (*) Qurayza [koo-RAY-zeh]. It changed its name from Yathrib after coming under a new religious government in 622 AD. The Battle of the Trench was fought to defend this city, whose forces won the Battle of Badr. For 10 points, name this city that Muhammad led after the Hijra, the second holiest in Islam.
tossups.answer: Medina [or Madinah] <AF, WorldHist>

tossups.question: The coincidence of the constellation Libra with an event in which diyas are used to make offerings to this deity [emphasize] is a reason why it is considered auspicious to balance financial accounts under Libra. In Orissa, white owls are considered good luck because this deity is always accompanied by one. This deity emerged along with Kamadhenu, Airavata, Varuni and the apsaras during the (*) churning of the ocean of milk. Families may clean their houses in order to appease this goddess and bring wealth to the household. This goddess, who is typically depicted as “Padma” standing on a lotus, is the dedicatee of Diwali. For 10 points, name this goddess of knowledge and fortune who chose Vishnu as her consort.
tossups.answer: Lakshmi <WA, Myth>

tossups.question: This scientist is the alphabetically first namesake of a formula that relates parabolic PDEs with stochastic processes, which can be used to solve the Black–Scholes model; he names that model with Mark Kac [cots]. This physicist proposed that hadron collisions may be analyzed via a “parton shower.” While performing calculations for “loops” on objects named for this man, diverging integrals may be dealt with via a process that this man called “hocus-pocus,” that of (*) renormalization. Constructs named for this man represent antimatter as moving backwards along the horizontal, or time axis. This physicist compiled Six Easy Pieces and Six Not So Easy Pieces as subsets of his three-volume lectures on physics. He won a Nobel Prize for his work on quantum electrodynamics with Schwinger and Tomonaga. For 10 points, name this Caltech physicist whose namesake “diagrams” depict particle behaviors.
tossups.answer: Richard (Phillips) Feynman <WA, Phys>

tossups.question: This denomination is the only one that still uses the Anaphora of Saint Gregory in its liturgy. The calendar of this denomination ends with five days called Pi Kogi Enavot. This denomination is unique among modern Christians for using the crux ansata, a cross with a loop or circle replacing its topmost bar. In May 2017, members of this denomination were attacked near Minya. In 2015, (*) ISIL militants released video of people from this denomination being decapitated in Libya. This church granted autocephaly in 1959 to a southern neighbor, the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church. For 10 points, name this non-Chalcedonian Christian denomination whose current pope, Tawadros II, lives in Alexandria.
tossups.answer: Coptic Orthodox Church [do not accept or prompt on “Orthodox”] <VC, Rel>

tossups.question: W. D. Snodgrass argued that this author allegorized the bad effects of masturbation in one story by reading it in the context of this author’s essay “Pornography and Obscenity.” In a story by this author, a mother explains to a son who is bound for Eton College that “If you’re lucky you have money” in a house that is “haunted” by the phrase “There must be more money!” In that story by this author, Hester’s child (*) Paul is able to predict the victors of races by riding a toy in his room. A sensational 1960 obscenity trial against Penguin Books resulted from a publication of this author’s novel about an affair between Oliver Mellors and Constance. For 10 points, name this author of “The Rocking-Horse Winner” and Lady Chatterley’s Lover.
tossups.answer: D. H. Lawrence [David Herbert Lawrence] <WA, Short>

tossups.question: This quantity divides a factor K and is subtracted by the maximum glass transition temperature in the Flory–Fox equation. This quantity and the radius of gyration can be measured by performing static light scattering experiments on polymers in a partial Zimm analysis. The square root of three times the ideal gas constant and temperature is divided by this quantity to find the root mean square velocity of a molecule. The polydispersity index gives the ratio of the (*) weight average and number average forms of this quantity. This quantity is inversely related to the rate of effusion of a gas by Graham’s law. Setting density times RT over the pressure in a manipulation of the ideal gas law gives this quantity. For 10 points, name this quantity, the sum of the atomic masses of a molecule.
tossups.answer: molecular weight [or molar mass; or molecular mass; prompt on mass; prompt on weight] <SB, Chem>

tossups.question: Art installations along this river designed to tell historical stories were created by the Confluence Project. Near this river, an Air Force test released enormous amounts of radioactive iodine as part of the “Green Run.” It names a 1964 international treaty governing dam construction under which the Keenleyside Dam was built, separating the Arrow Lakes. This river’s Hanford Reach was used to cool the reactors that produced the plutonium used in the Trinity test. Finishing a huge (*) power station on this river resulted in the reservoir known as FDR Lake. The Barlow Road allowed travelers to bypass part of this river. Along this river, Fort Clatsop was visited by the Corps of Discovery on the Lewis and Clark expedition. The Grand Coulee Dam was built on – for 10 points – what river that made up much of the Oregon Trail?
tossups.answer: Columbia River <RY, AmHist>

tossups.question: Two architecture firms from this city, DK-CM and The Decorators, collaborated to design a glass lighthouse featuring translucent polycarbonate windows near a waterfront here. A twisted skybridge called the “Bridge of Aspirations” connects a ballet school in this city to its opera house. Qatar owns a 95-percent share in a Renzo Piano-designed pyramidal skyscraper in this city, where an art museum houses a 34,500-square-meter-long (*) Turbine Hall. This city’s 30 St. Mary Axe houses a skyscraper resembling an egg, affectionately nicknamed “The Gherkin.” This home city of The Shard is also where Christopher Wren redesigned 52 churches after a fire swept through in 1666. For 10 points, name this European city that houses St. Paul’s Cathedral.
tossups.answer: London <SB, OVisArt>

tossups.question: A poem by this author that opens “My Sorrow, when she’s here with me” exemplifies how this author aimed to articulate “the sound of sense” better than other English writers. This poet observed “Crusoe was cast away, Thoreau was self-cast” in discussing inspirations for a poem about a “a broken drinking goblet like the Grail.” This author of “My November Guest” noted that “The work of hunters is another thing” in one poem, and imagined (*) two ways that the world might end in “Fire and Ice.” This poet imagined a conversation between a man who notes “My apple trees will not get across” and one who says “But here, there are now cows” and repeats his father’s saying “Good fences make good neighbors.” For 10 points, name this author of “Mending Wall.”
tossups.answer: Robert Frost (the second poem is “Directive”) <WA, Poetry>

tossups.question: This thinker argued that the key distinction of Adam Smith from the Physiocrats was his development of a concept of value “in general.” This thinker described how, in a free market, a comparison to a “universal equivalent” results in the predominance of the concept of a measure of “definite quantities of congealed labour-time” called (*) “exchange value,” as contrasted with “use-value.” Borrowing from a colleague’s work on England, this thinker described the unemployed as a “reserve army of labor” whose function was to depress workers’ wages. He argued that a feeling of “alienation” results in the modern economy because workers do not own their own product. For 10 points, name this author of Das Kapital.
tossups.answer: Karl Marx <WA, SocSci>

tossups.question: Damage to this organ can be tracked with a calcium-binding protein primarily found in it called S-100B. To prevent damaging part of this organ, it is necessary to limit the rate of sodium restoration in hyponatremia. Vasospasm in this organ is treated with the drug nimodipine. This organ is the site of berry aneurysms, which can occur in the circle of Willis. A disorder of this organ involves a microtubule-associated protein forming “fibrillary tangles.” (*) Subarachnoid hemorrhages cause ischemia in this organ, where tau proteins are deposited in CTEs and Alzheimer’s disease. For 10 points, name this organ whose regions include the pons, the corpus callosum, and the frontal lobe.
tossups.answer: brain [prompt on central nervous system or CNS] <RY, Biology>

tossups.question: When this monarch was requested to perform the king’s touch, he replied, “God give you better health and more sense.” Forces loyal to this king killed John Graham of Claverhouse, a figure commonly referred to as “Bonnie Dundee.” This king’s entrance to the League of Augsburg caused it to be known thereafter as the Grand Alliance. His subordinates orchestrated a massacre of a disobedient clan in a cave at (*) Glencoe. This king sailed on a ship to Brixham at the invitation of a group known as the “Immortal Seven.” The first Jacobite risings took place during the reign of this king, who won the Battle of the Boyne. For 10 points, name this Dutch nobleman who ascended to power alongside his wife Mary in the Glorious Revolution.
tossups.answer: William of Orange [or William III of England; accept Willem for “William”; prompt on William or Willem] <VC, BritHist>

tossups.question: A participant in this event reportedly consumed a hundred Chicken McNuggets a day because he thought that most other foods here looked odd. Steven Spielberg withdrew from the planning of this event in order to protest the War in Darfur. The symbol for this event was a stylized dancing man in white against a red background. The New York Times questioned whether some participants in this event were actually (*) sixteen years old, despite passport showing otherwise. People living near this event were restricted from driving using a scheme based on license plate number in order to control pollution, and factories were closed in nearby Hebei province. For 10 points, name this athletic event that took place largely in the “Bird’s Nest” stadium in Beijing.
tossups.answer: 2008 Summer Olympics [or Beijing Olympics until “Beijing” is read] <VC, Other>

tossups.question: Giorgio Vasari, who claimed that this artist learned perspective from his friend Filippo Brunelleschi [broo-neh-LESS-kee], chose to preserve this man’s work rather than destroy it while working on an altarpiece for Cosimo de Medici. This artist worked with his brother Giovanni on a Madonna for the center panel of the Pisa altarpiece. He illustrated the phrase “Render unto Caesar what is Caesar’s” in a work that uses one-point perspective centered on the face of (*) Jesus surrounded by disciples and shows a man paying a tax collector. This quattrocento [kwah-troh-CHEN-toh] artist depicted a crucifixion in a barrel vault in The Holy Trinity, and showed Saint Peter taking a coin out of a fish’s mouth in a work in the Brancacci [brahn-KAH-chee] chapel. For 10 points, name this artist of The Tribute Money.
tossups.answer: Masaccio [or Tommaso di Ser Giovanni di Simone] <WA, Painting>

tossups.question: A writer responds to Claude Duchet’s claim that this novel has a “mania for duplication” by calling it the “added element” that lets fiction “compete with the real world”. In another book, Enid Starkie’s argument that this novel’s writer forgot what color its protagonist’s eyes were is rebuked by Geoffrey Braithwaite. After a chance meeting at the opera Lucia di Lammermoor, a man and a woman in this novel have (*) sex in a moving carriage. Berthe [bairt] is the daughter of a man in this novel who is driven out of business by the pharmacist Monsieur Homais [oh-may]. In this novel, Rodolphe and Leon have affairs with the wife of a country doctor named Charles. For 10 points, name this novel by Gustave Flaubert.
tossups.answer: Madame Bovary (The leadin is from The Perpetual Orgy by Mario Vargas Llosa) <RY, LongFic>

tossups.question: A proposition within this subject was called a “tissue of nonsense” in a Bertrand Russell article about the “Teaching of” one of its theorists. Methods drawn from this subject are used to demonstrate the title concepts of a book that defines everything that exists as either a “substance” or “mode.” The ability of one man to learn this subject is used as proof of that people experience “recollection” or anamnesis, so they have knowledge from their (*) past lives. The title subject is demonstrated in an “order” describable by this word’s adjectival form in Baruch Spinoza’s Ethics. Socrates teaches this subject to a slave in the dialogue Meno. For 10 points, name this subject discussed extensively in Euclid’s Elements, which concerns shapes.
tossups.answer: geometry [or geometrical order; prompt on math or mathematics or even maths or science] <WA, PhilO>

tossups.question: This operation can be performed using Hensel lifting in the Berlekamp–Zassenhaus algorithm. According to Fisher’s theorem, a statistic is only sufficient if a PDF can have this operation performed on the PDF with the statistic. The householder transformation is the first step on a method to perform the QR type of this operation. A number is called wasteful if the result of this operation has more digits than the number. The general (*) number field sieve is the most efficient way to do this operation classically. The difficulty of doing this for large numbers is essential to the security of RSA. For all numbers greater than one, the prime type of this operation produces a unique result according to the fundamental theorem of arithmetic. For 10 points, name this operation that breaks a number down into several products.
tossups.answer: factorization [accept word forms like factorizing; accept matrix decomposition] <JL, Math>

tossups.question: John Cornwell wrote a book criticizing a leader of this country who authorized a message criticizing “the myth of race and blood” titled Mit brennender Sorge [ZOR-guh] to be distributed in Germany. Upon formal recognition, this country’s leaders were paid less than promised under the Law of Guarantees, but were honored by the construction of a “Road of Conciliation.” A policy opposing birth control was agreed to in a (*) 1959 meeting in this country in a document titled “Of Human Life.” Before this country was created, several men were called “prisoners” in the hill for which this country is named due to refusing to recognize authorities. It was created by the signing of the Lateran Treaty between its leader and Benito Mussolini. For 10 points, name this country whose head of state is the Pope.
tossups.answer: Vatican City (State) [or Stato della Città del Vaticano; or Status Civitatis Vaticanae; do not accept or prompt on “Papal States” or “Holy See” since those aren’t countries] <WA, ContHist> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: In a play by this author, Giovanni makes a rabbit-head birdseed soup with ingredients that Antonia and Margherita hide in their clothes, pretending to be pregnant. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of the comic Can’t Pay? Won’t Pay! who also wrote a play in which Inspector Bertozzo interrogates “the Maniac,” who reveals that a replica of a bomb is actually functional.
Fo staged several performances of The Barber of Seville, an opera based on Pierre Beaumarchais’s [boh-mar-SHAY’s] plays about this man, which include one about his Marriage to Suzanne.

Fo’s early play Mistero Buffo takes its title from this Russian writer’s play Mystery-Bouffe. This prominent writer of the early Soviet Union wrote the play The Bedbug and the poem A Cloud in Trousers.

bonuses.leadin: Benard cells form in a type of this process in which a layer of fluid is heated from below. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this form of heat transfer in fluids, contrasted with conduction and radiation.

To solve convection problems one can employ the Boussinesq approximation, which ignores values for this quantity unless it is multiplied by the gravitational acceleration, g. It also multiplies g and h to give the gravitational potential energy for a fluid and is constant during incompressible flow.

This dimensionless number gives the ratio of convective to conductive heat transfer across a boundary by multiplying the convective coefficient by the characteristic length and dividing by the thermal conductivity of a fluid.

bonuses.leadin: Visitors to this city might be amused by local nicknames for its landmarks and monuments, such as “the Tart with the Cart” and “the Stiletto in the Ghetto.” For 10 points each:
answer: Oscar Wilde [or Oscar Fingal O’Flahertie Wills Wilde] <VC, Other>
parts: Name this city where Nelson’s Pillar used to stand until it was blown up by terrorists in 1966. This city’s historic bridges cross the River Liffey as it flows into the Irish Sea.

“The Tart with the Cart” is a nickname for Dublin’s statue of this woman, a fishmonger who sold “cockles and mussels, alive, alive-o.” A folk song about this woman tells of how she owned a wheelbarrow before dying tragically in the third verse.

A Dublin statue depicting this famous Irishman reclining on a large rock is controversially nicknamed “the Queer with the Leer.” Directly across from him is a statue to this man’s estranged wife, Constance Lloyd.

bonuses.leadin: Otto Rank connected world mythology through a psychoanalytic approach in a work about the “Myth of the Birth of” these people. For 10 points each:
answer: heroes [accept The Hero With a Thousand Faces]
parts: Name these people, whose stories experience a pattern of departure-initiation-return according to mythographer Joseph Campbell.
The theory that heroes’ stories and journeys all follow a single pattern was given this name by Joseph Campbell. George Lucas applied this idea to Star Wars.
Campbell’s approach is rooted in the approach of this psychoanalyst, particularly in his concept of archetypes. He split with Sigmund Freud over his notion of the “collective unconscious.”

bonuses.leadin: This man united the Greek cities into the Panhellenion and, according to Cassius Dio, built a city to honor the victim of a human sacrifice. For 10 points each:
answer: Nile River [or an-Nil; or Neilos] <VC, Ancient>
parts: Name this Roman emperor who famously loved the youthful Antinous and built a wall in Britain.

Antinous was from this territory, which was unified with Pontus in a Roman province. Rome gained control of this territory after its last native king, Nicomedes IV, bequeathed it to Rome upon his death.
The city of Antinoöpolis was built by Hadrian on the shores of this body of water, where Antinous drowned.

bonuses.leadin: Ludwig Wittgenstein argued that a “private” example of this thing would be impossible using the example of a man who writes “S” in a diary. For 10 points each:
answer: Elizabeth Anscombe [accept G. E. M. Anscombe or Gertrude Elizabeth Margaret Anscombe] <WA, PhilO>
parts: Name these things. Translation involves converting from one of these things to another.
This Ludwig Wittgenstein book introduces the philosopher’s concept of “language-games” and argues that issues with language use are at the root of most philosophical problems.
This Catholic philosopher did the first English translations of Wittgenstein’s work. In a 1958 article, this philosopher introduced the term “consequentialism.”

bonuses.leadin: This religious movement was the subject of a study by anthropologist James Mooney. For 10 points each:
answer: Boxers [prompt on Society of Harmonious Fists by asking for the common name]
Mormons [accept members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints or members of the LDS Church; prompt on Christians] <LS, AmHist>
parts: Name this religious movement begun by Wovoka after seeing a solar eclipse.

Ghost Dance believers thought that their shirts would make them impervious to bullets, drawing comparisons to this Chinese rebel group that the US joined an 1899 intervention against. They were given their common name in English from their symbol of fists.
Some reports indicate that members of this religious group adopted Ghost Dance practices. Eber Howe wrote a book criticizing this religious group that promoted theories about Solomon Spalding.

bonuses.leadin: The author’s friend noted “Everything in this book has happened but a coup!” when calling this book prophetic; of course, many coups proceeded happened in the country soon after. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Chinua Achebe novel set a fictional country resembling Nigeria. Its protagonist Odili is betrayed by his girlfriend for Nanga, who uses his position as Minister of Culture get rich via corruption.
Achebe also criticized this novel’s author Joseph Conrad as a “bloody racist” for questionable depictions of Africans in the Congo Free State.

This other Joseph Conrad novel also imagines a fictional country, that of Costaguana, whose long history of violence is brought to an end by the caudillo Ribiera. It is titled for an “incorruptible” man in Sulaco.

bonuses.leadin: NOTE TO MODERATOR: Do not read the prompts in the first bonus part to teams. Many languages implement this kind of function by using arrow operators, and they are frequently used as arguments to higher-order functions like map and fold. For 10 points each:
answer: anonymous function [or anonymous expression; accept but DO NOT REVEAL lambda function or lambda expressions]
parts: Name this type of function that is necessarily not assigned a name.
Anonymous functions are implemented in many languages such as Python and C++ using this type of expression. Alonzo Church developed the “calculus” named for this Greek letter.

Church’s lambda calculus originally did not have these categories, but he later constructed one that only had a constructor for the “function” version. Float, int, and string are simple versions of these categories.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Orientalism in 19th-century French art, for 10 points each.
answer: The Women of Algiers in their Apartment
parts: This Neoclassical French painter depicted a sensuous turbaned woman from a harem with far too many vertebrae in his iconic La Grande Odalisque.
This painting by Eugène Delacroix shows a trio of figures sitting around a hookah with a black servant woman attending to them at right.
This Jean-Léon Gérôme painting, which is on the original cover of Edward Said’s Orientalism, shows a nude woman with her back to the viewer holding an animal, with a blue wall forming the background.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Ottoman military presence in and around Greece, for 10 points each.
parts: A chain was drawn across the Golden Horn to defend against the Ottoman navy during their 1453 siege of this city, the capital of the Byzantine Empire.

This building served as an Ottoman mosque before being used as a gunpowder store, in which capacity it was severely damaged during a 1687 Venetian siege. Some of this building’s sculptures were nearly lost with the sinking of the ship Mentor after being removed from it in the early 19th century.
Despite four invasions, this Ionian island never came under Ottoman control. The conflict between Athens and Corinth over this island was one of the proximate causes of the Second Peloponnesian War.

bonuses.leadin: In Islam, public adoption of this status is limited by the boundaries of the awrah, which describes an area of the body from the naval to the knees. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this practice that gymnosophists engaged in freely. Some Christian naturists observe this practice in emulation of Adam and Eve’s lifestyle in the Garden of Eden before the Fall.
In Jainism and this faith, the term “sky-clad” describes people practicing religious nudity. Adherents of this faith are instructed to “be naked in your rites” in the Charge of the Goddess.
In one story, this man goes out among his servant girls in a state of undress, and is reproached for this by his wife, Michal. He conquers a stronghold of the Jebusites and makes it his capital.

bonuses.leadin: The protein pVHL [P-V-H-L], which is mutated in von Hippel–Lindau disease, adds this protein to the protein HIF-1 [H-I-F-one]. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this small protein that is covalently added to other proteins to target them for destruction by the proteasome [PRO-tee-uh-zome]. Its name suggests that it is found in all eukaryotic cells.
Ubiquitination is one of many posttranslational modifications available for these positively-charged proteins. Chromatin consists of DNA wrapped around these proteins.

Ubiquitin is added at this amino acid; because ubiquitin itself has seven of this amino acid, ubiquitins can be added to each other, especially at their residue 48, which regulates proteasome trafficking.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about classical music used in the Fantasia series of movies, for 10 points each.
parts: An animated version of “The Steadfast Tin Soldier” accompanies this composer’s Piano Concerto No. 2 in the movie Fantasia 2000. His String Quartet No. 8 opens with his namesake D-S-C-H motif.

Bette Midler notes that Disney almost used a piece from this country titled Schwanda the Bagpiper instead of Shostakovich’s Piano Concerto No. 2. A composer from this country wrote the Glagolitic Mass.

Al Hirschfeld’s caricatures for the New York Times inspired the third piece in Fantasia 2000, which used this George Gershwin composition to set the scene. This boisterous work opens with a long clarinet glissando.

bonuses.leadin: In a story by this author, tremendous explosions “like a rifle” go off “bang bang bang” in the heart of Bowman. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of “Death of a Traveling Salesman,” who wrote another story about Phoenix Jackson traveling through the woods to get medicine.

In this novella, a traveling salesman starves himself to death; he is earlier reminded by his mother to catch the seven o’clock train and reprimanded by the chief clerk for only speaking behind his bedroom door and giving answers of “Yes” and “No.”
This author wrote about Willy Loman, who travels to Boston to sell real estate and see his mistress, in the play Death of a Salesman.

bonuses.leadin: The bulk of these works are addressed to a “Fair Youth” including one set in “the chronicle of wasted time” with “beauty making beautiful old rhyme.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name these works, the most famous of which asks “Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?”
In “Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?”, Shakespeare finds the comparison inadequate because he believes his beloved “art more” of these two qualities. Name both.
Sonnets 127 through 154 are addressed to this figure, a mistress of Shakespeare whose eyes “are nothing like the sun” and whose hair is compared to wires in Sonnet 130.

bonuses.leadin: Thanks to this man winning a Nobel Prize in Literature in 2016, we’re now allowed to write a non-trash bonus on him. For 10 points each:
answer: “Ma” Rainey [or Gertrude Malissa Nix Pridgett] <WA, OAudArt>
parts: Name this folk singer of “Like a Rolling Stone.”

“Scarborough Fair” was a favorite of many songwriters, including Bob Dylan, who was inspired by a recording to write “Girl from the North Country.” Identify the four plants mentioned in the second line of “Scarborough Fair.”
Dylan listed among his musical influences this blues singer, who was known as the “Mother of Blues.” She sang while Louis Armstrong played the trumpet on many songs by the Georgia Jazz Band.

bonuses.leadin: In the Kastle–Meyer test, the reduced form of this compound becomes bright pink after interacting with hemoglobin. For 10 points each:
answer: half-equivalence point [do not accept or prompt on just “equivalence point”; do not accept “endpoint”] <SB, Chem>
parts: Identify this chemical compound with formula C20H14O4, which is frequently used in an elementary chemistry lab procedure.
Phenolphthalein is a common indicator employed in the acid–base form of this lab procedure which measures the amount of an unknown substance in a solution.

In an acid-base titration, this is the point at which the pH of the solution is equal to the pKa of the acid. This point is different from the point at which the moles of analyte and titrant are equal.

bonuses.leadin: In an ancient dynastic foundation myth, a king spends several years focusing on standardizing weights and measures before trying to deal with this event, and sacks Gun for failing to do so. For 10 points each:
answer: Great Flood of the Yellow River
parts: Identify this event, which was dealt with by a clever administrator who was assisted by the deity Hebo [huh-boh] and, in some accounts, a yellow bear or dragon.
This legendary flood survivor is sought out by one of his descendants in the Epic of Gilgamesh because he is said to possess the secret of immortality; instead, he tells Gilgamesh to return to Uruk.
Many early flood-myths are reflected in the story of this later Biblical character, who builds a huge ark that lands on Mount Ararat.

bonuses.leadin: A Tibetan monk created the ‘Phags-pa [POGS-pah] script for a ruler of this dynasty that he served as Imperial Preceptor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this dynasty, which was later overthrown by the Red Turban Rebellion led by Zhu Yuanzhang [joo y’wen-jong], who became known as the Hongwu emperor.

Kublai installed prince Wonjong [wun-JOHNG] as the ruler of this peninsula’s Goryeo [kor-yuh] dynasty, allowing the Mongols to use it to launch two failed invasions of Japan. The Goryeo lend this peninsula its English name.
The Yuan dynasty built a new capital called Khanbaliq to replace the earlier Mongol capital at this site. A Flemish missionary named William of Rubruck visited Mongke Khan at this city.
